title: Chest Pain in a 45-Year-Old Male

initial_presentation.vitals: BP 140/90, HR 95, RR 18, Temp 98.6Â°F, O2 Sat 98%
initial_presentation.summary: A 45-year-old male presents with acute onset chest pain. Pain is substernal, pressure-like, started 2 hours ago. Associated with mild dyspnea and diaphoresis.

full_case.history: Patient reports chest pain that started suddenly while at rest. Pain is 7/10, substernal, radiates to left arm. No relief with rest. History of hypertension, no known cardiac disease. Family history of early MI in father at age 50. Smokes 1 pack/day for 20 years.
full_case.exam: Appears anxious but comfortable. No JVD, no peripheral edema. Heart: Regular rhythm, no murmurs. Lungs: Clear bilaterally. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.
full_case.labs: Troponin I: 0.8 ng/mL (elevated), CK-MB: 8.2 ng/mL (elevated), BNP: 450 pg/mL (elevated), D-dimer: 0.3 (normal), CBC: WNL, BMP: WNL
full_case.imaging: ECG: ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF. Q waves in inferior leads. CXR: Normal heart size, clear lungs.

gold_standard.problem_representation: 45-year-old male with acute onset substernal chest pain, elevated cardiac enzymes, and ST elevation in inferior leads. High-risk features include smoking, family history, and typical presentation for acute MI.
gold_standard.management: 1. Immediate activation of cardiac catheterization lab for primary PCI. 2. Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 325mg, clopidogrel 600mg loading). 3. Atorvastatin 80mg. 4. Beta-blocker if no contraindications. 5. Monitor for complications (arrhythmias, heart failure). 6. Smoking cessation counseling.

differential.name: ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
differential.why_fits: Classic presentation: acute chest pain, elevated troponin, ST elevation in inferior leads, high-risk factors (smoking, family history)

differential.name: Unstable Angina / NSTEMI
differential.why_fits: Could present similarly with chest pain and elevated enzymes
differential.why_not: ST elevation on ECG is diagnostic for STEMI, not NSTEMI

differential.name: Aortic Dissection
differential.why_fits: Can present with chest pain and hypertension
differential.why_not: No pulse deficits, no widened mediastinum on CXR, ECG pattern is classic for MI

common_mistakes: Not recognizing ST elevation as STEMI
Missing the need for dual antiplatelet therapy
cognitive_bias_traps: Anchoring bias: Focusing only on chest pain without considering ECG findings
Premature closure: Assuming it's just anxiety without checking cardiac enzymes
Availability bias: Over-relying on normal vitals to rule out serious disease
teaching_points: STEMI is a time-sensitive diagnosis requiring immediate reperfusion therapy (PCI or thrombolytics).
ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF indicates inferior wall MI, which can be associated with right ventricular involvement.
Dual antiplatelet therapy is essential in acute coronary syndrome to prevent stent thrombosis.
Smoking is a major modifiable risk factor for coronary artery disease and should be addressed in all patients.
